title: Popular Sydney beach closed over second shark sighting
text:
Australia Day

beachgoers have been ordered out of the water at a popular location on

Sydney

's Northern Beaches after a shark was spotted for the second time today.

title: The price of gold just hit a new record high amid global tensions
text:
The price of gold has hit a new record high, ﻿surging past $7200 per ounce.

Its value grew by more than 60 per cent in 2025 and a single ounce is now worth ﻿about $US5024 ($7271).

Experts predict that figure will continue to climb in 2026 due to the uncertain geopolitical climate, especially in the United States.

Gold has broken the $US5000 barrier and is predicted to break the $6000 barrier later this year. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"Our current forecast suggests that prices will peak at around $US5500 ($7960) later this year," Philip Newman, director at Metals Focus, told Reuters.

Independent analyst Ross Norman told the outlet gold prices are forecast to surge as high as $US6400 ($9263) per ounce this year.

He also predicted an average price of ﻿$US5375 ($7779) for the rest of the year.

The price of gold is surging because it's a safe-haven asset.

That means it retains or increases in value during periods of market turbulence, which can be caused by geopolitical uncertainty.

Uncertainty caused by, for example, ﻿tensions between the US and NATO over US Trump's Greenland plans, ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia despite US-brokered peace talks, and Trump's many tariffs and regular threats to impose more.

All of this has sent investors flocking to gold, which won't lose its value if tariffs or conflict tanks a specific market or currency.

READ MORE: Ferry carrying hundreds capsizes in the Philippines ﻿

﻿Some everyday Australians have followed suit.

Aussies queued for hours to get in on the gold rush late last year, lining up outside mints and bullion stores to buy the precious metal.

Others cashed in by selling old gold jewellery , which tends to have a higher gold content than new pieces, for quick cash.

﻿But small businesses like Juju Gems Jewellery in Sydney's south have struggled as the price of gold keeps climbing.

Larna Cooper and Julie Modica are struggling to keep up with surging gold prices. (Instagram/@jujugems.jewellery)

When the price of gold broke the $US4000 ($6071) barrier ﻿for the first time﻿ in October 2025, owners ﻿Larna Cooper and Julie Modica had to raise prices or risk going under.

"Every week we're checking and the gold price has jumped, and it's just adding a lot of extra work to us and making it really hard for us," Cooper told 9news.com.au at the time.﻿

title: Ferry carrying hundreds capsizes in the Philippines
text:
A ferry with more than 350 people on board sank in the southern

Philippines

after midnight and rescuers have saved at least 215 passengers and retrieved seven bodies, officials said today.

title: 'A gift from the Australian people'
text:
Sporting legend Cathy Freeman has been awarded Australia's highest honour, a little more than 25 years after she sent the nation into a frenzy with her Olympic gold medal at Sydney 2000.

Other notable names to be appointed as a companion of the Order of Australia (AC) tonight include former premiers Kristina Keneally, Annastacia Palaszcuk and Steven Marshall, and former federal finance minister Mathias Cormann.

In all, nearly 1000 Australians were recognised in the﻿ Australia Day 2026 Honours List, including awards in the Order of Australia (General and Military Divisions), meritorious awards, and recognition for distinguished and conspicuous service.

Cathy Freeman crossing the finish line and winning gold in the 400 metres at the Sydney 2000 Olympics. (Getty)

It's just the latest in a glittering list of achievements and awards for Freeman, undoubtedly one of Australia's greatest athletes, responsible for the country's most iconic sporting moment.

She already counted Australian of the Year, Young Australian of the Year, Sport Australia Hall of Fame Legend status and the Order of Australia Medal alongside her Olympic gold and silver medals and three Commonwealth Games golds in her trophy cabinet.

The Kuku Yalanji and Birra Gubba woman was recognised for "eminent service to athletics as an international competitor and ambassador, to positive social impact across the community, to the reconciliation movement in the spirit of unity and inclusion, and as a role model to youth."

Freeman told The Sydney Morning Herald she intended to use the honour as a platform to unite Australia.

"Mum said this is a gift from the Australian people and I wouldn't have looked at it that way, but my mum has incredible wisdom. So I sort of just stopped overthinking it and took it in the spirit it's supposed to be received in," she said, adding her mum was "all about unity".

"I just want to be who I am, be authentic. My achievement and my story is always going to touch on things like Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander perspectives, Olympism, track and field, elite sport, women in sport, the themes are diverse and varied."

Cathy Freeman celebrates with her gold medal after winning the Women's 400m final at the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. (Getty)

Freeman described the award as "quite mind-bending".

"I set out to be the best athlete that I could be for myself and then all of a sudden this whole world unfolded right before my very eyes, and it just continues to expand, and it continues to be a wild ride, let me tell ya," she said.

Palaszczuk, who won widespread support among Queenslanders but angered many in the rest of the country by limiting the local impact of the COVID-19 pandemic through harsh border restrictions, was praised for her recognition to public health.

She was also recognised more generally for her time as premier and service to educational equity and multiculturalism.

Then Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk during a press conference following a national cabinet meeting at Parliament House in Canberra on Wednesday 6 December 2023. (The Sydney Morning Herald)

Rob Hirst, the Midnight Oil drummer who died just days ago follow an almost three-year battle with pancreatic cancer , was appointed a member of the order for his service to music.﻿

The Council of the Order of Australia highlighted former federal finance minister Cormann for his contributions to government reform, multilateral affairs and international economic development.

The Belgian-born Australian politician became secretary-general of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) shortly after leaving the Senate.

Former NSW leader Kristina Keneally was recognised for her services as premier, as well as her later years as a federal senator.

Former South Australian premier Steven Marshall was recognised for his service to business, people with disability, governance and board positions.﻿

In addition to the 680 recipients of awards in the General Division of the Order of Australia (10 AC, 38 AO, 160 AM and 472 OAM), today's Honours list includes:

22 recipients of awards in the Military Division of the Order of Australia.

187 Meritorious awards

60 Distinguished and Conspicuous awards

You can search the table below for the full list of honourees.﻿

READ MORE: Police respond to potential sighting of accused triple murderer

Governor-General Sam Mostyn said the honourees reflected Australia's values for service, community, kindness, curiosity, tenacity, and care.

"Congratulations to everyone recognised in the Australia Day 2026 Honours List," she said.

"As the list so vividly showcases, so many Australians continue to give the best of themselves across many endeavours, in the interest of others. It is rewarding to see an increase in the number of awards, which reflects more nominations and recognition of the many Australians who inspire the best in all of us."

title: How communities across the country are marking Australia Day
text:
Australia Day festivities have officially begun, with events taking place across the country — from a fun run in the north, to traditional dance and smoking rituals across a number of capital cities and ceremonies welcoming the country's newest citizens.

Today — January 26 — represents the date of British settlement in Australia, marking when the First Fleet arrived at Sydney Cove in 1788.

First Nations protests on January 26 have a long legacy Every year, January 26 is marked by protests and events organised by Indigenous groups across Australia. It's a legacy that dates back 88 years.

Here's how people across the country are marking Australia Day this year.

ACT

The National Citizenship and Flag Raising Ceremony opened Australia Day commemorations in Canberra this morning, to the tune of Land Down Under, played by the Royal Military College Duntroon band.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, Governor-General Sam Mostyn and National Australia Day Council chair John Foreman AM were among those in attendance on the shore of Lake Burley Griffin.

The Australian Federation Guard greeted Mr Albanese with a general salute, while Ms Mostyn received a vice-regal salute before inspecting the guard.

Governor-General Sam Mostyn inspects Australia's Federation Guard at the Canberra ceremony. (AAP: Mick Tsikas)

Aunty Roslyn Brown, a Ngunnawal elder, performed the Welcome to Country, followed by the Australian National University Chamber Singers who sang the national anthem.

Two Australian flags, two Aboriginal flags and two Torres Strait Islander flags were carried into position by 36 volunteers, including Australian of the Year alumni and their families and First Nations representatives from communities across the country.

The Royal Australian Navy's 808 Squadron made a fly-past in an MH-60R Seahawk, with a giant flag dangling below, followed by Royal Australian Air Force flyovers from a CA Wirraway and an E-7A Wedgetail.

Muggera Dancers from the New South Wales Northern Rivers region then performed a cleansing ritual and spirit dance, calling on all ancestors to come together as one for the ceremony.

The prime minister also presented 23 new Canberrans — hailing from India, New Zealand, Turkiye, the United States of America, Nigeria, Malaysia, Nepal and the United Kingdom — with their citizenship certificates this morning.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese standing alongside Canberra's new citizens and the most recent Australians of the Year. (AAP: Mick Tsikas)

"At the very heart of the pledge that you make today to our laws, to our values and to our people, is the respect for our common humanity that defines Australia," Mr Albanese said.

"Love, not hate. Hope, not fear. Optimism, not negativity. And, indeed, unity, not division.

"That is the Australia … that you are pledging to be a part of, and to make yourselves part of the Australian story. Welcome home."

NSW

Hundreds gathered beneath the iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge in the early hours of this morning, meeting at Barangaroo Reserve for the annual WugulOra Morning Ceremony.

For 23 years, WugulOra — which means One Mob — has celebrated continuous culture on the traditional lands of the Gadigal people, of the Eora Nation, combining optimism for a shared future with tradition and sacred ritual.

Doonooch Dancers, from Yuin Nation/Nowra, performed a traditional dance for the Sydney crowd. (ABC News: Max Tillman)

The continuous culture of Australia's first people was celebrated on Gadigal land this morning. (ABC News: Adam Griffiths)

The event began with a performance from the Doonooch Dancers, from the Yuin Nation on the NSW South Coast, where First Nations artists and performers celebrated traditional dance and storytelling throughout the morning.

The ceremony included a performance of the Australian national anthem, sung in two languages — English and Eora, which is spoken by traditional custodians of the land where the ceremony took place.

A huge crowd gathered at Barangaroo Reserve for the annual WugulOra Morning Ceremony this morning. (ABC News: Max Tillman)

NT

It was an early and wet start for some in Darwin, with Australia Day celebrations kicking off in the drizzling rain around sunrise.

Hundreds of locals dressed up and gathered at the Darwin Convention Centre, where they warmed up with Zumba dancing before taking on Oz Run, a 2.5km and 5km fun run through the city.

Rain wasn't enough to stop the Australia Day fun run in Darwin. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

The event wasn't just for the Top End's fitness fanatics, with locals of all ages — some pushing prams and accompanied by their children — joining the fun.

Wet season rain wasn't enough to dampen the festivities, with locals invited to enjoy live entertainment at the Darwin Waterfront through the morning.

Matching outfits were a great way for participants to keep track of their friends and family in the Australia Day crowds. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Hundreds of locals dressed up and gathered at the Darwin Convention Centre for this year's Oz Run. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Queensland

Thunderstorms failed to stop hundreds of people turning out to mark Australia Day in the garrison city of Townsville, in Queensland's north.

Premier David Crisafulli praised locals for attending the flag-raising ceremony despite drenching rain, alongside members of the defence force.

Jezzine Barracks troops and the Queensland premier attended Townsville's official flag-raising ceremony this morning. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

"There you are, standing in the rain to acknowledge [Australia Day]," he said

" It's weather like this that defines who we are as a nation and a state … boy, oh boy, have we copped it in recent times. "

Inger Van Essen and her family, who moved to Townsville from Sweden just a few weeks ago, were among those present, marking their first Australia Day as locals.

The Van Essen family recently moved to Townsville from Sweden, and today marked their first Australia Day as Queenslanders. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

"We wanted to join the feeling, and see what it's all about," she said.

"We really enjoyed it — it's raining, but it's nice and there's a lot to see, and our sons like to see all the military stuff."

Despite today's wet weather, hundreds of Queenslanders showed up to mark the occasion in Townsville. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

Mackay has also been hit with wild weather in recent times, with the local bowling club hosting a fundraiser for flood victims today.

Meanwhile, further south in Brisbane, locals are sizzling through the city's hottest Australia Day in almost three decades.

In the city's CBD, new Queenslanders will be honoured at the Australia Day citizenship ceremony at South Bank.

SA

Encouraging reflection, connection and respect, Adelaide's Mourning in the Morning was held at Elder Park on Kaurna country earlier today.

The First Nations-led ceremony recognises Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, their culture and stories.

Mourning in the Morning celebrates Indigenous culture with speakers, musicians and dancers. (ABC News: Angelique Donnellan)

Welcoming both Indigenous and non-Indigenous South Australians to the banks of Adelaide's River Torrens/Karrawirra Parri this morning, the event centred on truth-telling, reflection and cultural continuity.

Organisers estimated up to 3,000 people were present, including Uncle Major "Moogy" Sumner — a Ngarrindjeri elder and member of SA's Voice to Parliament body — who performed a Welcome to Country, which was followed by a traditional smoking ceremony.

Uncle Major "Moogy" Sumner performed a Welcome to Country on the banks of Adelaide's River Torrens/Karrawirra Parri this morning. (ABC News: Angelique Donnellan)

A traditional smoking ceremony blessed the space on Monday morning. (ABC News: Angelique Donnellan)

As the day goes on, Adelaideans are set to experience the hottest Australia Day of all the capital cities today, with temperatures expected to reach a maximum of 45 degrees.

Victoria

A crowd of political, multicultural and religious leaders converged at Government House, just south of the Melbourne CBD, this morning ahead of an official flag-raising ceremony.

In her speech, Margaret Gardner spoke about recent times of division and conflict and advocated for unity. (ABC News)

Victorian Governor Margaret Gardner gave a speech about "times that try our souls", referencing the recent Bondi Beach terror attack, climate change concerns and global conflicts that she said had spilled into "discrimination and hatred on our shores".

"It will be our lost opportunity if we allow these times to divide us," she told the crowd.

Among those in attendance was Thanh-Kham Tran-Dang OAM, who fled Vietnam in 1979 and became a founding member of the Australian Vietnamese Women's Association.

Thanh-Kham Tran-Dang OAM fled Vietnam in 1979 to come to Australia and says it is the "land for opportunity". (ABC News)

"I am very proud to be here on Australia Day with the governor," she said.

" We had connections with Holland — the Netherlands, we had connections with the USA, but we chose Australia because we believed that Australia is the land for opportunity. "

A number of Australia Day events are also taking place across regional Australia, including in Torquay on Victoria's Surf Coast, where a large crowd gathered from 5:30am for the fourth annual Pilk Purriyn truth-telling event.

The Wadawurrung Traditional Owners Corporation says thousands came together as First Nations People shared ceremony, truth, reflections and song. (Supplied: Wadawurrung Traditional Owners Aboriginal Corporation)

Thousands came together as First Nations locals shared ceremonies, truth, reflections and music, according to the Wadawurrung Traditional Owners Corporation.

Aunty Colleen Howell, the daughter of a Stolen Generation survivor, shared her story through song, and the event concluded with the crowd dancing to Yothu Yindi's hit track Treaty, to symbolise the historic treaty signed in Victoria's parliament last year.

A large crowd gathered for the truth-telling event In Tourquay. (Supplied: Wadawarrung Traditional Owners Aboriginal Corporation)

The Wadawurrung Traditional Owners Corporation co-chief executive Bek Devlin described the event as "powerful and deeply moving".

"The huge number of people who make a conscious effort to rise early on a public holiday and join us for this event shows there is genuine support, and indeed a deep yearning for reconciliation in this country — that you can still be proud and love your country, while holding great sorrow for the way our nation came to be," she said.

"We step into the future with hope and purpose, working towards a more inclusive and equitable future for all Australians.

title: Wild winter storm leaves hundreds of thousands of Americans without power
text:
A massive winter storm in North America has brought sleet, freezing rain and snow to much of the US, with subzero temperatures disrupting air and road traffic.

Tree branches and powerlines snapped under the weight of ice, and hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses in south-east America were left without electricity.

The ice and snowfall were expected to continue into Monday followed by very low temperatures that could cause "dangerous travel and infrastructure impacts" for days, according to the National Weather Service.

Heavy snow has been falling in the Ohio Valley, including in Cincinnati. (AP: Joshua A Bickel)

Heavy snow was falling from the Ohio Valley to the country's north-east, while "catastrophic ice accumulation" threatened from the Lower Mississippi Valley to the Mid-Atlantic and south-east.

"It is a unique storm in the sense that it is so widespread," weather service meteorologist Allison Santorelli said.

"It was affecting areas all the way from New Mexico, Texas, all the way into New England, so we're talking like a 2,000-mile (3,200km) spread."

Freezing rain is supercooled rain that falls as liquid but freezes upon impact.

Nashville, Tennessee, is one of the many areas in the US affected by wild winter weather. (AP: Holly Meyer)

Emergency declarations

US President Donald Trump had approved emergency declarations for at least a dozen states by Saturday.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency pre-positioned rescue teams and commodities in numerous states, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said.

In New York state, communities near the Canadian border saw record-breaking subzero temperatures, with Watertown registering minus 37 degrees Celsius and Copenhagen minus 45C, Governor Kathy Hochul said.

There have been heavy winter storms in Toronto, Canada. (Reuters: Wa Lone)

Coping with the storm

In Corinth, Mississippi, construction equipment maker Caterpillar told employees at its re-manufacturing site to stay home on Monday and Tuesday.

"The sound of the trees snapping, exploding and falling through the night have been unnerving to say the least," resident Kathy Ragan wrote on Facebook.

In Clarksdale, Mississippi, Sanford Johnson said enough snow and sleet fell that few motorists ventured out.

"I had to break it to my youngest daughter that the play date she scheduled likely won't happen today. We have no plans on driving," Mr Johnson said.

US snowstorm triggers flight cancellations A monster snowstorm is moving across the US, cancelling thousands of flights, knocking out power and snarling major roadways with ice.

In Nashville, Tennessee, Jami Joe, 41, feared her electricity might not last as ice-heavy limbs from oak and pecan trees continued to crash around her house.

"It's only a matter of time if a limb strikes a powerline," she said.

Because of icy roads, Josh Martin figured he and his wife, Misti, were "locked in" for a while at their home on a steep hill in Columbia, Tennessee.

"Getting in and out of the neighbourhood is not an option," he said.

"I can get down because gravity will take me, but I could not get back up."

Times Square, New York, during a winter storm. (AP: Heather Khalifa)

On Manhattan's Upper East Side, January Cotrel enjoyed the fresh snow on a block that was always closed during snowstorms for residents to sled, throw snowballs and make snowmen.

"I pray for two feet (61cm) every time we get a snowstorm. I want as much as we can get," she said.

"Let the city just shut down for a day and it's beautiful, and then we can get back to life."

Lights out and flights delayed

As of Sunday morning, about 213 million people were under some sort of winter weather warning, Ms Santorelli said.

Hundreds of thousands of customers were without power according to poweroutage.us, with Tennessee and Mississippi hit especially hard.

Some 11,500 flights were cancelled on Sunday and more than 16,000 delayed, according to the flight tracker flightaware.com.

Airports in Philadelphia, Washington, Baltimore, North Carolina, New York and New Jersey were among those impacted.

People in Philadelphia have been adjusted to the winter weather. (AP: Matt Rourke)

Bitter cold makes things worse

The danger would continue after the ice and snow, Ms Santorelli warned.

"Behind the storm it's just going to get bitterly cold across basically the entirety of the eastern two-thirds of the nation, east of the Rockies," she said.

That means ice and snow will not melt as fast, which could hinder efforts to restore power.

In New York City, Mayor Zohran Mamdani said that at least five people who died were found outside as temperatures plunged on Saturday, although the cause of their deaths remained under investigation.

He urged people to stay inside and off the roads.

"We want every single New Yorker to make it through this storm," he said.

A big winter storm has dumped sleet, freezing rain and snow across much of the US, including Lake Michigan, Chicago. (AP: Nam Y Huh)

Two men died of hypothermia related to the storm in Caddo Parish in Louisiana, according to the state health department.

Across the affected areas, schools and universities announced that classes would be cancelled or held remotely on Monday.

The NBA postponed games in Memphis and Milwaukee on Sunday because of dangerous travel conditions.

The Dallas Mavericks tried twice to fly to Milwaukee for their Sunday night game against the Bucks, but conditions would not allow it.

A decision to postpone was announced a few hours before tip-off.

Food that had been prepared for the game was donated to shelters in the Milwaukee area.

Earlier on Sunday, a game between the Denver Nuggets and Memphis Grizzlies was postponed about three hours before tip-off.

Plunging temperatures have disrupted traffic, with officials in many areas asking people to stay off the roads. (AP: Nam Y Huh)

Recovery could take time

In Oxford, Mississippi, police appealed for residents to stay home.

Utility crews were also pulled from their jobs during the overnight hours.

"Due to life-threatening conditions, Oxford Utilities has made the difficult decision to pull our crews off the road for the night," the utility company posted on Facebook early on Sunday.

"Trees are actively snapping and falling around our line men while they are in the bucket trucks."

Oxford city officials posted dramatic photos on social media of slick roads and ice-coated trees sagging or breaking under the added weight.

US President Donald Trump has approved emergency declarations for at least a dozen states, due to wild weather. (AP: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

In Tennessee, emergency officials urged motorists to give crews of workers space to treat roads as drivers had been crashing into them.

Icy roads also made travel dangerous in north Georgia, where the Cherokee County Sheriff's office posted on Facebook, "You know it's bad when Waffle House is closed!!!" along with a photo of a shuttered restaurant.

Whether the chain's restaurants are open — known as the Waffle House Index — has become an informal way to gauge the severity of weather disasters across the south.

AP

title: Paying money just to breathe in one of the world's most polluted cities
text:
Sourabh Yadav says he has "forgotten what it's like to have a window open" at his home in Delhi.

Originally from Chhattisgarh, a small state in central India, the 26-year-old filmmaker moved to India's capital for university and has lived there for eight years.

"Summers are brutal in Delhi, so we try to go outside more during winters," he told the ABC.

"But now, given India's Air Quality Index (AQI), these little joys seem tarnished."

Sourabh Yadav says Delhi's residents usually venture outside for longer amounts of time during winter. (Supplied: Sourabh Yadav)

AQI is the system used to measure how polluted the air is and ranges from 0–50 for "good" to 500 for "severe".

Since November, Delhi's AQI has hovered between 300 and 400, more than 20 times the limit recommended by the World Health Organization.

Even the air inside Mr Yadav's home is poor, so he bought an air purifier.

"When I turned it on for the first time, it displayed a near 300 AQI. After a few minutes, it managed to go down to around 20," he said.

However, Mr Yadav said having an air purifier in Delhi was "a privilege" as they sell for between 10,000–20,000 Indian Rupee ($162–$340).

"That's around the cost of monthly rent in Delhi, even for middle-class people," he said.

"Having to pay that kind of money just to breathe is not always in people's capacity."

Sourabh Yadav's air purifier displays an AQI of 291, which he says is considered very high. (Supplied: Sourabh Yadav)

Money aside, Mr Yadav said air purifiers also had limitations.

"They only work for small spaces, which is why I keep it in my bedroom," he said.

"But as soon as I go into my living room or kitchen, I'll start to feel dizziness or get a headache.

"It means people will need multiple air purifiers in their home, which most cannot afford."

'Simple joys' come with health risks

Home to more than 30 million people, Delhi and its surrounding region routinely rank among the world's most polluted cities.

India has six of the 10 most polluted cities globally, and Delhi tops the chart, according to an October report from Switzerland-based air quality monitoring database IQ Air.

In November, Delhi's AQI stood at 344, a level considered "severe" and dangerous to breathe. (AP: Manish Swarup)

Each winter, farmers burn crop residue in nearby states and cooler temperatures trap the smoke that mixes with vehicle and industrial emissions.

India's Central Pollution Control Board reported some improvements in recent years due to favourable weather conditions and anti-pollution measures.

But some studies have found Delhi's air pollution has been more severe than previously estimated.

The poor air quality has impacted nearly all aspects of life.

Hybrid learning has become the norm at schools and universities, offices close regularly, and people mostly stay indoors.

Mr Yadav said he has also lost other "simple joys" in life, such as enjoying a roadside chai.

He said buying a chai at a "tapris" — roadside shops that sell tea — was part of his regular routine and a big part of Indian culture.

"But now standing on a footpath with your mask off to sip tea feels a little uneasy," he said.

Sourabh Yadav says he misses his routine of drinking tea from roadside stalls. (AP: Manish Swarup)

Now Mr Yadav buys packed tea to have at home.

"Sometimes it makes you angry," he said.

" It makes me wonder, God, this air is the very life you breathe. How can you not care? "

Delhi's residents are fed up.

In November, hundreds gathered at Delhi's India Gate in a rare protest, urging authorities to act.

India's government has taken steps to address air pollution, one being its launch of the National Clean Air Program (NCAP) in 2019.

Its aim was to cut PM2.5 pollution by 20 to 30 per cent by 2024 — from 2017 levels — which was later revised to a more ambitious 40 per cent reduction by 2026.

Citizens protest against what they say is the government's lack of action to combat air pollution in Delhi. (AP: Manish Swarup)

However, policing Delhi's air quality will require an "inter-sectoral response" according to Poornima Prabhakaran, an epidemiologist and public health researcher at Ashoka University.

"This is due to the multiple sources of pollution," Dr Prabhakaran said.

"Transport is a major source, as well as industrial activity, road and construction and demolition dust.

" There must be a concerted effort to address all sources to begin to lower the hazardous levels of pollution. "

Air pollution a silent killer

Delhi's air pollution is shortening the life expectancy of its residents by as much as 12 years, according to a recent Air Quality Life Index report by the Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago.

"What we generally see during poor air quality times is an increased number of patients who present to the hospital with exacerbation of their asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)," said Saurabh Mittal, an expert in diseases of the respiratory system at All India Institute of Medical Sciences.

Delhi residents use air purifiers to improve the quality of air inside their homes. (AP: Manish Swarup)

"Young patients, who were previously asymptomatic, also come with eye, nasal and throat irritation and a persistent cough."

Dr Mittal said the pollution also had an impact on some people's mental health.

"Patients with psychological disorders can face low mood and more fatigue in poor air quality," he said.

And in the long term, there was a higher risk of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease, Dr Mittal added.

"Higher degree of hypertension and accelerated memory loss are some long-term effects as well," he said.

When breathing comes at a financial cost

Delhi resident Ashna Sharma and her family have struggled with respiratory issues for years.

"Stepping outside is nearly impossible, and inside our home every single room now has an air purifier," Ms Sharma said.

Ashna Sharma says she and her family have spent more on doctor visits in Delhi in the last two months. (Instagram: @ashnaaasharmaa)

The 26-year-old counselling psychologist and content creator said she was "genuinely worried" about her health, but even more for her parents.

"They are ageing, and this is not the quality of life they deserve," she said.

Ms Sharma and her family have also racked up more bills as they cope with the air pollution.

"In just the last two months, we've spent more on medicines and doctor visits than anything else," she said.

" We can't even do something as basic as go for a walk. "

Looking back over the years, Ms Sharma said the only time she remembers breathing clean air was during the COVID lockdown "when vehicles were off the roads".

"Between Diwali firecrackers, overpopulation, and stubble burning, Delhi has become almost unlivable," she said.

Cutting emissions 'at the source'

Critics say only long-term measures to cut emissions can bring real relief.

South Asia is the global hotspot for air pollution. Can it be fixed? Measures to curb pollution such as installing more pollution monitors and pushing for a switch to cleaner fuels are yet to yield significant results.

"Delhi's air improves only when emissions are cut at the source," said Roxy Mathew Koll, a climate scientist at the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology.

"These emissions are from industries, vehicles, waste and crop burning," Dr Koll said.

He said cuts in emissions must also be complemented by cleaner energy, efficient transport, and coordination with neighbouring states.

But Delhi's geography made this challenging, he said.

"Delhi sits in a basin between the Himalayas and Aravallis mountains where weak winter winds and temperature inversions trap pollutants near the surface," he said.

title: Why a US 18yo rejects the 'underdog' tag against world No.1 Sabalenka
text:
Not long after booking an Australian Open quarterfinal berth, Iva Jović expressed quiet confidence about her chances of defeating upcoming opponent, Aryna Sabalenka.

As match-ups go, few are tougher than facing world number one Sabalenka on a court where she has twice lifted the championship trophy.

It would be easy to suggest Jović is simply enjoying the innocence of youth, given she is 18 and the youngest player inside the top 100 on the WTA rankings.

But the American is not a naïve teenager, blindly caught up in the moment at Melbourne Park.

Sabalenka's approach to being world number one Aryna Sabalenka reveals why she has not changed since topping the world rankings.

The world number 27 has unwavering self-belief in her game, and few could argue about her potential after watching her destroy Yulia Putintseva 6-0, 6-1 in the fourth round.

"I don't really feel like there is a lot of house money or underdog mentality that I'm feeling," Jović said.

"Because I don't feel like I have been playing anything outside of my comfort zone or outside of my normal level.

"I have come from two other tournaments where I was playing every day and winning a lot of matches, as well.

"So this week and the level that I'm showing right now doesn't really feel much different than that.

"it's just another week that I'm winning more matches, which is nice to see."

Iva Jović is the youngest player in the top 100 on the WTA rankings. (Getty images: Clive Brunskill)

Jović's run to the last eight has been impressive.

She is yet to drop a set and among her victories was a 6-2, 7-6 (7/3) defeat of seventh seed Jasmine Paolini, who is a two-time major finalist and former world number four.

Jović did not need to play herself into form, having made the final and semifinal of two Australian Open lead-up events, in Hobart and Auckland, respectively.

Her 2025 season underlined her status as a star on the rise, highlighted by her win at the Guadalajara WTA 500 event as a 17-year-old.

Jović ready for Sabalenka

Sabalenka, who won the Australian Open in 2023 and 2024, will be a different proposition to Jović's previous opponents in Melbourne.

She arrived at the tournament on the back of winning the Brisbane International and has barely been challenged on her way to the quarterfinals.

Jović, though, is not intimidated by the Belarusian.

Aryna Sabalenka has twice won the Australian Open. (Getty Images: Fred Lee)

While buzzing to have come this far at the season-opening major, she sees no reason why she cannot compete against Sabalenka.

"I'm just excited. I'm in the quarters, which is amazing for me," Jović said.

"So you're going to be playing one of the best players at this stage of the tournament. That's what you want.

"I'm just trusting the level that I have been able to put out and hopefully that will be enough."

Tuesday's quarterfinal will be the first time Sabalenka and Jović have played each other on the WTA Tour.

title: Live: Defending Australian Open champ sent packing as Pegula dominates Keys
text:
Jason Kubler and Marc Polmans have won an all-Australian encounter against James McCabe and Li Tu to advance to the quarterfinals of the men's doubles.

Kubler and Polmans broke once in each set, taking out the match 6-4, 6-4 in one hour 28 minutes.

McCabe and Tu's run ends. They knocked out British number one seeds Julian Cash and Lloyd Glasspool, which was a brilliant result.

But they didn't quite cope with their opponents today and were chasing the game for most of the event.

Kubler and Polmans will now face French 12th seeds Sadio Doumbia and Fabien Reboul for a place in the last four.

Speaking afterwards, Jason Kubler was asked about his fiancee Maddison Inglis, who will take on second seed Iga Świątek in the fourth round.

He said he was very proud of Inglis, who has had an amazing time at Melbourne Park this year.

"No matter what happens tonight ... she's had an incredible run from quallies (Australian Open qualifying).

"I just hope she goes out and enjoys it."

title: Heartbreak as home owner discovers roof was ripped off by Tropical Cyclone Luana
text:
The owner of a coastal retreat in Western Australia's far north says she was heartbroken when she discovered her home had been "all but destroyed" by Tropical Cyclone Luana.

Luana crossed the WA coast as a category two system on Saturday, bringing heavy rain and damaging winds to remote communities across the Dampier Peninsula.

The ex-tropical cyclone, now a tropical low, is tracking inland across the Kimberley.

Pat Channing, who runs Mercedes Cove Exclusive Retreat, an Aboriginal-owned and operated business, with her husband David, was in Broome, about 160 kilometres to the south, when the cyclone crossed.

The damaged property was Ms Channing's family home at Mercedes Cove and she heard about the destruction from managers on the ground.

Roof blown off

These pictures show the debris, caved-in plaster and insulation foam covering the kitchen and living area.

Pat Channing says she was heartbroken when she heard the property had been destroyed. (Supplied)

Ms Channing said they had only recently restored the roof after ex-Tropical Cyclone Hayley, which crossed earlier this month.

"Then this other cyclone ripped the roof off and dropped the ceiling in the lounge and kitchen and water damaged everything," Ms Channing said.

The Mercedes Cove managers told Ms Channing that waiting out the cyclone was "frightening and terrifying".

They were staying at another residence on the site.

Pat Channing runs Mercedes Cove Coastal Retreat with her husband David. (ABC News: Erin Parke)

"The wind was horrendous, they couldn't get out in the morning for at least 3 to 4 hours to make any assessment of the damage," Ms Channing said.

"Luckily, all our accommodation for the tourism season was not affected so that's a plus, I suppose."

None of the tourist accommodation at Mercedes Cove was damaged by Tropical Cyclone Luana. (Supplied)

Ms Channing said the house held precious memories of her family, friends and retreat guests, which would not be forgotten.

"Twenty years [ago] my hubby built that and I helped where I could … we had a wonderful 20 years with our children and our grandchildren," she said.

Heavy rainfall forecast

DFES Kimberley Superintendent Leon Gardiner said he was aware of structural damage to a building at Mercedes Cove.

The Mercedes Cove property was hit by damaging winds and heavy rainfall. (Supplied)

"DFES is on stand-by to provide assistance but emergency services support has not been requested at this time," he said.

"The damage from the cyclone crossing overnight was mainly concentrated to Derby with 12 requests for assistance on Sunday.

"Mainly for fallen trees blocking access or leaning on homes."

The tropical low will take "several days" to move south through the Kimberley, Pilbara and southern interior, according to Superintendent Gardiner.

Leon Gardiner advised people in affected areas to stay up to date with the latest warnings. (ABC Kimberley: Andrew Seabourne)

"[This] could bring heavy rainfall and flooding to those areas this week," he said.

"There are flood and storm warnings current on Emergency WA with the latest information and directions for people in those areas to prepare and stay safe."

title: Pub joey a story of the challenges facing country WA's 'underground' wildlife carers
text:
Anthony "Oz" Ostigh is an unlikely kangaroo carer who wanders around his mining town wearing a stockman's hat and a crochet bag with an eight-month-old joey named Roofus.

Roofus is one of many orphaned kangaroos Mr Ostigh has taken under his wing.

Mr Ostigh lives in Boddington, about 130km south-west of Perth, where he is his community's unsanctioned kangaroo carer.

A joey in the pub is a strange sight for some patrons. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

He is not a registered wildlife carer — a requirement under WA law — but partly does the job because the nearest registered carer is more than 100km away from town.

The other reason is that caring for vulnerable kangaroos is his life's passion, which began as a boy.

"They follow you everywhere. They want the attention, they come up for their cuddles," Mr Ostigh said.

When the joeys reach 12 to 18 months in age, Mr Ostigh releases them.

In Roofus's case, he was given to Mr Ostigh by a Boddington local who found the joey as a "pinky" in the pouch of his deceased mother.

Mr Ostigh has cared for several orphaned joeys, but has a special bond with Roofus. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

Plenty of company

In a joey's early months, Mr Ostigh brings them on his day-to-day errands, including to the pub and grocery store.

Roofus is a regular vistor to the pub in Boddington. (ABC South West: Anna Cox)

"They need to be fed pretty frequently, so they come with me," Mr Ostigh said.

He said Roofus was a welcome visitor to the local watering hole.

"It's quite amazing really, some of the miners are big burly blokes covered from head to foot in tattoos," he said.

"You'd think they're not the sort of person who would come up and want to pat a roo."

Publican Julie McNamara said it was not uncommon to see animals being cared for by kind-hearted locals.

Julie McNamara says the joey is the pub's cutest regular. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

"All of the beautiful people and souls in Boddington, they raise whichever animals that are injured … it's just the normal," she said.

" It's not abnormal to have someone that comes through with a sheep on a leash or a goat on a leash. "

Pub patron Lou Chapman said Mr Ostigh and Roofus made him proud to be a Boddington local.

"What he's doing is relaying the fact that if you've got an injured animal, he's prepared to take it in and help," said Mr Chapman.

"It's good, it's human nature to be nice, even to a furry friend."

Oz Ostigh has been taking care of Roofus since he was just a baby joey. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

'Underground' wildlife carers

In order to care for wildlife in WA, a licence from the Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) is required.

Registered kangaroo carer and founder of Roo Rescue, Kim Mitchell, said obtaining a licence was becoming increasingly inaccessible.

"It shouldn't be that hard, it's not rocket science," Ms Mitchell said.

She said the rigorous licensing process had forced many carers to work "underground", without official clearances.

The Boddington Hotel is 130 kilometres south of Perth. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

"We're only doing it because it's a calling and the animals need us and there is nowhere else for them to go," Ms Mitchell said.

"If the volunteers and wildlife carers stopped, we'd be in a dangerous situation of losing massive amounts of animals."

DBCA does not condone the informal care of native animals, but said there was a pathway for temporary care arrangements.

"A person can apply to DBCA to temporarily possess fauna that is injured or abandoned until it recovers or can fend for itself to ensure successful release back into the wild," a spokesperson said.

title: Influx of influencers leaves tennis fans frustrated at Australian Open
text:
After a record number of people streamed through Melbourne Park's gates for the first day of the Australian Open this year, Tennis Australia boss Craig Tiley said: "Cricket's in December. Our objective is we want to own January."

Part of that strategy is to make the tournament about more than just tennis. Over the three weeks — including qualifying week and main draw — the sporting precinct becomes a behemoth of brand activations, activities and entertainment.

There's also the slew of influencers who descend on the tournament and post relentlessly across social media. Many get invited to premier experiences and seating by brands in exchange for content to their followers, which can range from a few thousand to millions.

They have helped Tiley and co make the event not just the place to be during January, but the place to be seen at.

The 2026 Australian Open has attracted record crowds throughout the tournament. (Getty: James D. Morgan)

Many long-time tennis fans say this is changing the look, feel and experience of going to the Australian Open, with comparisons drawn to the fashion-focused Spring Racing and the changing culture of the Australian Grand Prix.

With this, some frustration has been levelled at influencers and content creators by the general public — many of whom have been going to the tournament for years — with the inundation coinciding with thousands being forced to wait in queues for hours for matches while they get increased access.

One fan posted online about having to wait five hours in the sun to see Stan Wawrinka play at Kia Arena during week one.

Emily Wade, 28, says she is a genuine fan who is finding it personally frustrating to see the influx of influencers take up seats at marquee matches when others who would genuinely appreciate being there for the tennis are finding it increasingly inaccessible through overcrowding and higher ticket prices.

"I've been seated behind influencers before and I've witnessed them on their phones, talking, leaving early and I personally don't think it's a good look," Wade told the ABC.

"The only comparison I have is the AFL/AFLW, which has very minimal influencer presence, so that doesn't affect my experience as much as the tennis, where the influencer presence is growing every year."

Loading Instagram content

Kirsty Stekel, 37, said she missed when the Australian Open was more about dressing in team colours rather than fashionably.

"I love the AO no matter what, but [I'm] definitely mourning the era when you could get cheap ground passes, hop between courts and matches with ease and everyone would show up in groups dressed in countries' colours to support players — not having to worry about looking chic or fashionable," Stekel said.

"Wearing national colours brought so much energy to the crowd and the day and it's rarely seen anymore."

The role of content creators and influencers at the AO

Most influencers are invited by certain brands or companies to events across the tournament, while organisers have granted increased access to content creators this year.

Tennis Australia director of content Brie Stewart told Code Sports: "We understand that they're coming anyway, and we want to be a part of the story they're creating."

But one popular TikTok influencer, who talked to the ABC on the condition of anonymity, said they were surprised at the level of pressure placed on influencers to be creating content by organisers.

"I think it was 20 posts [across the tournament] to even be allowed into the AO creator lounge," they said. The creator lounge is a designated section within Tennis HQ, where creators can film, edit and work.

"Some people don't think we work for our money but 20 edited videos [is] a lot of time out of our day. I did the math, that's a minimum [equivalent] of $60K in TikToks," the influencer said.

Some Aus Open fans frustrated by 'Opening Week' The Australian Open's "Opening Week" has seen record crowds, but some fans are frustrated and disappointed by the confusing messaging.

The tournament used a "tier system" where creators were rewarded with certain perks based on the quantity of content they posted and "impressions" from their audience.

The "rewards" included, among other perks, guided backstage tours, accreditation access to the AO grounds, going into the running for AO Reserve seats, AO partner events and seats to the quarterfinals, semifinals and men's and women's final.

The reward system kicked off the week prior to the AO starting.

One fan online wrote: "I think the AO just played the game really well. They got all the influencers in the week before to spruce up the vibe, show off the food and the fun as well as the tennis and it worked."

The influencer added that they felt people would always find negative things to say about "influencing" because it was "a dream job".

"We do f**k all and get paid a shit-ton," they said.

While brands have their own collaboration deals with influencers, Tennis Australia has not paid any or covered their travel costs.

'Not one way to be a fan'

Many tennis fans have also voiced frustration at the lack of tennis etiquette from certain influencers and groups of fans who are more concerned with getting content than watching the matches.

One fan told the ABC that a group of influencers sat in front of them at a match, took a bunch of photos with a particular branded product and then left without watching any of the match.

Dr Kasey Symons, lecturer of communication specialising in sports media at Deakin University, said there would always be some good and bad apples among big groups.

Loading Instagram content

As someone who researched fan culture in sports, she said people needed to move away from the idea that there was one kind of sports fan, or one way to do fandom.

"We need to embrace how all fans want to connect to sport, whether that be as lovers of the sport and high consumers of the competition and match analysis, to casual fans who enjoy the atmosphere, [and] social media users who are engaging in an online community," Symons told the ABC.

"There are always going to be fans that cross the line and annoy other fans, but they are not reflective of the wider group.

"There are traditional fans who can be disruptive to the enjoyment of other fans, and influencers and new fans and social media users can get it wrong too.

" This has to become a broader discussion on how to be a good fan rather than what is the 'right' way to be a fan. "

But online creator Nicole Bridget pointed out on TikTok that who got invited as guests to events like the Australian Open could still be quite rigid and exclusive.

She said the issue she had was with brands and agencies not inviting diverse people and "making it very clear only skinny creators are invited to the AO events for yet another year because apparently if you're curvy it means you don't like sport".

Some women sport creators have also been frustrated at their lack of being championed by brands during the events.

Meanwhile, others have found it hard to watch female influencers post content flaunting and laughing at their lack of tennis knowledge in a space in which they have worked hard to be taken seriously.

More women learning about the sport

Atara Thenabadu, 25, said she saw similarities with changing fan cultures of tennis with the F1, which brought in a lot of young female fans after the success of the Netflix documentary series, Drive to Survive.

"When it comes to the question of whether influencers 'deserve' to be there, I can't help but feel that there are undertones of sexism in some quarters, whether realised or not, that uphold the so-called sacred guardrails of professional sport that for years acted as barriers against women who were interested in learning about the sport," Thenabadu told the ABC.

Morgan Riddle, girlfriend of US tennis player Taylor Fritz, has been credited by many for getting more young women into the tennis. (Getty: Cameron Spencer)

The Kansas City Chiefs in the NFL had an uptick in female viewership after singer Taylor Swift started attending games with her partner, Chiefs player Travis Kelce. While this was a sugar hit for some, it did convert others into NFL fans, particularly women who long felt excluded from the sport or intimidated by its scene.

Super Bowl champ calls out Taylor Swift haters Philadelphia Eagles superstar Saquon Barkley says he does not understand why Taylor Swift was booed at the Super Bowl, adding that she is part of the reason the NFL is growing internationally and taking games to Australia.

"That said, I do believe, based on online discourse, that there have been repeated instances of a lack of engagement with the sport itself, such as not watching matches or talking loudly, which I don't think is appropriate," Thenabadu said.

Thenabadu added that when considering the two perspectives — while there wasn't a simple solution — she believed the overcrowding and long-line issues fell at the feet of Tennis Australia, rather than with influencers invited by brands.

"From my perspective … I don't feel jealousy or envy when watching influencers attend; however, I would be lying if I said I wasn't surprised by others voicing discontent with influencers who have shown little to no interest in the sport being included," she said.

title: 1960s films restored in hope of enticing new migrants to regional Australia
text:
Darryl Bruhn remembers he was about 10 years old when his dad, Brice, was filmed by an out-of-town crew while working at a limestone quarry near Mount Gambier, in South Australia's south east.

"For him it was just a normal day and the fact there was a film crew there … he would have been concentrating on his job," he said.

Little did he know, the film would be distributed around the world and seen by people who would end up moving to Australia.

Darryl Bruhn has travelled the world but still feels a strong connection to Mount Gambier, where he grew up. (Supplied: Darryl Bruhn)

The film crew was part of the Commonwealth Film Unit (now Film Australia), and was visiting the town to create a Mount Gambier edition of the Life in Australia film series.

The films — commissioned by the Department of Immigration in the 1960s — screened at embassies and High Commissions, particularly in the United Kingdom, to encourage migration to Australia.

Mount Gambier was one of 12 locations around Australia highlighted in the series, including major capital cities and other regional towns.

A glimpse into regional life

Released in 1964, the Mount Gambier film follows a local family through the rhythms of work and leisure in the region.

It showcases local industries such as forestry and cheesemaking, and highlights important locations including the hospital, Commercial Street and Brownes Lake.

Mr Bruhn does not remember much about the film from when he was a child, but parts of it were immortalised in the region.

"They had a whole lot of photographs that were taken at that time as part of that series and there was a photograph of [my dad] cutting limestone on a billboard on the entrance to Mount Gambier," he said.

"I think I did see the footage at some time later on, and then it was only probably 12-18 months ago when it popped up on Facebook."

The Mount Gambier Life in Australia film captured many places in the region 60 years ago, including the Valley Lakes precinct. (Supplied: National Film and Sound Archive)

Mr Bruhn moved to Adelaide about 20 years ago, but still visits family in the region about once a year.

"When I [drive] in, I'll come in from Millicent and I'll look up on the hill and see the lake and the tower ... that's always when something happens in my stomach," he said.

"When you enter the pine forest areas, that's what tells you that you're home in Mount Gambier.

" I guess there is some nostalgia about things that [people] remember and things that you've forgotten until you see something that triggers your memory. "

Selling regional Australia to migrants

Towns featured in the Life in Australia films were chosen because they were considered attractive for migrants.

Professor Kate Darian-Smith from the School of Historical and Philosophical Studies at the University of Melbourne said they were intentional marketing campaigns.

"The one on Mount Gambier, for instance, really highlights that this is a regional place where there is industrial growth," she said.

"They're not documentaries in the sense that they're not including those who are excluded; there is really no reference or mention of First Nations people … [and] no real addressing [of] any social or class divisions."

The Life in Australia films showcased an idealistic view of what it was like to live in Australia. (Supplied: National Film and Sound Archive)

Post-World War II migration in the 1950s and 60s was lower than expected, and the Australian government wanted to boost numbers.

"Those coming from Britain were always seen as the most desired cohort and the group of people Australia really wanted to attract," Professor Darian-Smith said.

"The key message is there are jobs there for migrants — both skilled and unskilled — and that the economy itself is modernising."

Professor Darian-Smith said the series was effective, but many did not stay longer than a few years.

"A lot of British migrants who were lured by films like this … found when they came, the reality was somewhat different," she said.

"Up to about 25 per cent of all migrants coming in the 50s and 60s returned to Britain or other countries of origin because the hype didn't quite ... [match] their own experience."

Restored for modern viewing

The Life in Australia films have now been re-released on YouTube in 4K by the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

The old hospital in Mount Gambier was a major employer for residents in the 1960s. (Supplied: National Film and Sound Archive)

Senior manager of the enterprises team with the archive, Bronwyn Dowdall, said digitising the archived film was not typical.

"The process is known as scanning and grading — not a restoration as such," she said.

"They're really interesting time capsules; definitely a portrayal of an idealised Australia — the Australia that the government at the time wanted the world to see."

The videos have been popular for those interested in looking back to the 1960s, as well as the locals who featured in the films.

"We're really hoping that people are able to engage with the material to look back and reflect on what their town was like at that time," Ms Dowdall said.

"It's always fun to see places that you're very familiar with … decades ago."

The National Film and Sound Archive's project allows people to see what the famous Blue Lake looked like 60 years ago. (Supplied: National Film and Sound Archive)

While the Life in Australia series has not been recreated since, its legacy lives on in the form of a booklet distributed by the Department of Home Affairs to new migrants.

Ms Dowdall said she would like to see what a modern version of the films would look like.

"The Commonwealth Film Unit doesn't exist anymore, so it would be interesting if anybody had that as a project," she said.

"There could be production companies that are interested … but productions like that can be really expensive."

title: Rail over the Derwent a distant memory as final pieces removed
text:
The last time a train travelled across the River Derwent was more than a decade ago, and it was carrying freight rather than passengers.

Hobart's rail corridor has sat unused since 2014, following the opening of the Brighton Transport Hub on the northern side of the river.

It has also been more than 50 years since passenger rail rolled into Tasmania's capital, although short heritage rides have recently commenced.

A Tasman Limited train winds through Hobart's northern suburbs in 1974. (trains-worldexpresses.com )

Despite this, there remained some in the community who wanted to see the railway returned to its former glory.

But the removal of the heritage-listed Bridgewater Bridge's main lift span this month marks, for some, the final nail in the coffin for Hobart's rail corridor.

Loss of rail connection a 'matter of regret'

Tasmanian Transport Museum president Jeff Bronstein said the loss of the Bridgewater rail crossing is deeply felt in Tasmania's rail heritage community.

"It's always sad and a matter of regret when you see railway infrastructure, especially iconic railway infrastructure like the Bridgewater Bridge, come to the end of its life and removed," he said.

Mr Bronstein said the physical structure was not the only thing lost, but also "all the stories and all the human activities that were involved with the construction, design and operation of the bridge".

He said it closes off future possibilities for rail.

"When a piece of infrastructure like rail is taken away, it's very difficult to restore it, to have it replaced, due to the costs involved with such large pieces of engineering," Mr Bronstein said.

The state government described the bridge as being in poor condition and requiring high maintenance costs, resulting in its removal.

It has been replaced by a four-lane bridge that opened to traffic in June 2025 and cost $786 million.

The new Bridgewater Bridge opened in June last year. (Supplied: State Growth)

Disused rail corridor to become rapid busway

The government is pushing ahead with plans to use parts of the northern suburbs rail corridor for a rapid busway.

The details are yet to be confirmed, and a broader business case is overdue for release.

Loading...

Once the business case is complete, the state government will seek additional funding from the Commonwealth for the busway.

There are also plans for the rapid bus system to connect to the yet-to-be-built Macquarie Point stadium precinct to help move large numbers of event goers.

But despite that, one group still hopes passenger rail will run through northern Hobart yet again.

Toby Rowallan from the Hobart Northern Suburbs Rail Action Group. (ABC News: Kate Nickels)

The Hobart Northern Suburbs Rail Action Group (HNSRAG) envisions an interconnected public transport network for the northern suburbs, where buses and park-and-ride facilities feed into train stations.

It believes trains would help ease congestion on Hobart's key arterial roads, as well to reduce urban sprawl, and increase housing density.

HNSRAG president Toby Rowallan said the removal of the old Bridgewater Bridge makes a future rail link "a little bit harder", though not impossible.

A visualisation of a 2013 plan for light rail in Hobart, since discarded.

Could Tasmania's passenger train service ever make a comeback? Passenger trains, along with trams and trolley buses, were once part of Tasmania's transport mix.

"It just means that we'd have to do that in stages. We'd have to go from Hobart to Granton first, and then once it was a success, it would be easy to justify reconnecting the railway and putting a stop on the other side of the river," Mr Rowallan said.

Servicing the broader Brighton municipality remains an important area of interest for him, as its "one of the highest areas of transport disadvantage".

"People can't afford a car and have reduced bus services, and now there is no other option possible because the rail line has been removed," he said.

The lift span on the old bridge has long been a feature in Hobart's northern suburbs. (Supplied: Department of State Growth)

Heritage train ride expansion still happening

Mr Bronstein said the museum's heritage train operations between Glenorchy and Berriedale, along with its plans to expand to Granton in the coming years, would not be affected by the removal of the old bridge.

But the removal of the rail crossing connecting both sides of the River Derwent will prevent any further expansion plans across the river.

"Once we've established our rail operations as far as Granton, it does become problematic for the museum not having a direct fixed rail link across the Derwent River."

The finished Bridgewater Bridge in Hobart. (Supplied: State Growth)

What happened to Hobart's trams? Which was the first Australian city to get an electric tram network? Melbourne? Sydney? Nope. Try Hobart. But where did they go?

He said the museum may eventually need to move locomotives using heavy equipment or set up a new depot near the old Bridgewater Junction station, but any solution was years away and would require government assistance.

"The costs of establishing a new fixed rail link would be prohibitive," he said.

While one option could involve bussing passengers across the new bridge as trains are moved separately, Mr Bronstein admits the idea is unlikely to be practical.

Keeping history alive

Even though the Bridgewater rail crossing has been removed, parts of its history will be preserved.

The Department of State Growth has agreed to give the museum access to some of the bridge's dismantled rail infrastructure.

Tasmania's most expensive infrastructure project opens to public Tasmania's largest and most expensive transport infrastructure project — the Bridgewater Bridge — has been opened to the public with thousands expected to walk it on foot.

"We are hopeful that we'll be able to get access to some welded rail. It's good quality rail. There's sleepers there, there's signalling points and those kinds of bits of infrastructure, signage et cetera," Mr Bronstein said.

He said the salvaged materials would be used to support the museum's plans to expand to Granton and establish a major western terminus.

" Aspects of it will still see the light of day in terms of railway operations. Just not the way it was originally intended. "

The department intends to incorporate elements of the old bridge into a future interpretive site, giving the structure a second life in the area's storytelling.

title: Why most Australians won't get a weekday off for Anzac Day in 2026
text:
For the first time since 2020, Anzac Day will fall on a Saturday this year, which means most Australians will not get a weekday off.

In 2026, only the Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia will have Monday, April 27, as a public holiday.

The ACT announced it will transfer the public holiday to the Monday, and said: "Anzac Day remains a national day of significance on the 25th April and all commemorative activities will be occurring on the Saturday."

In WA, the government has designated both the Saturday and Monday as public holidays.

For the first time since 2020, Anzac Day will fall on a Saturday this year. ( )

The reason comes down to the legislation in each state.

When Anzac Day falls on a Sunday, people in Queensland, South Australia, WA, the Northern Territory, and the ACT get the public holiday on the Monday per their state's laws, whereas those in New South Wales, Tasmania and Victoria do not.

So how does it all get decided, and how can you maximise time off from work?

Who can decide to offer a substitute public holiday?

In Queensland, if Anzac Day falls on a Saturday only the Minister for Industrial Relations, Jarrod Bleijie, can — by Gazette notice — substitute another day for a public holiday, according to the Queensland Holidays Act 1983.

But in January, Mr Bleijie said he would not be moving to substitute Anzac Day for another day as it fell on a Saturday, rather than a Sunday.

"My understanding under the legislation is the Anzac Day falling on a Saturday is the public holiday," he said.

"If it was to fall on a Sunday … it does then get substituted for a Monday.

"We have no intention to change [the legislation] at the moment. We're always in discussion with RSL Queensland and our veterans, but at this stage there's no plans to change that."

Queensland's deputy premier Jarrod Bleijie declined to give Queenslanders a substitute Anzac holiday. ( )

Queensland is not the only state that can shift its public holidays, with legislation in SA, NSW, the NT, and Vic also allowing for state government ministers to make one-off decisions.

In Tasmania, changes can only be made be legislative reform.

In relation to Anzac Day specifically, in the ACT, the Holidays Act 1958 outlines that if April 25 falls on a Sunday, the following Monday is a public holiday.

It is also currently legislated in WA, with the Public and Bank Holidays Act 1972 outlining that, when Anzac Day falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the next following Monday is also a public holiday.

When is the next public holiday?

Public holidays shared nationwide: New Years Day, January 1

Australia Day, January 26

Good Friday, April 3

Easter Monday, April 6

Christmas Day, December 25

Boxing Day, December 26 (plus substitute day on December 28 for most states)

With 2026 now underway, let's take a look at when public holidays will fall this year and how to make the most of them.

Mainstream public holidays are shared widely among the states and territories.

These include Christmas Day, Good Friday, and Easter Monday.

Some jurisdictions get a part-day holiday on Christmas Eve, with the day considered a public holiday after 6pm in Queensland and 7pm in SA and the NT.

All states and territories provide for an additional public holiday on December 28 because Boxing Day falls on a Saturday this year.

Labour Day differs between the states. WA will have a public holiday on Monday, March 2, while Vic will have public holiday a week later on Monday, March 9. Queensland will have a day off on Monday, May 4, while the ACT, NSW and SA will have their public holiday on Monday, October 5.

In the NT, the day is known as May Day and is held on May 4, while in Tas it is called Eight Hours Day and is held on March 9.

Tasmania's Labor Day-equivalent Eight Hours Day pays tribute to those who pushed for standard working hours. ( )

All the states and territories get a King's Birthday public holiday on Monday, June 8, apart from Queensland, which has theirs on Monday, October 5, and WA, which will observe the holiday on Monday, September 28, this year.

Beyond the classics, some states have unique, exclusive days off not shared by other states.

Queensland Queensland's unique public holiday this year is the Ekka holiday, which will fall on Wednesday, August 12. New South Wales NSW has a Bank Holiday on Monday, August 3, but it is not a declared public holiday and only retail bank branches and certain financial institutions are required to close, unless staff voluntarily choose to work. ACT The ACT will get extra holidays for Canberra Day on Monday, March 9, and Reconciliation Day on Monday, June 1. Northern Territory The NT will celebrate Picnic Day on Monday, August 3, and also get a post-7pm public holiday on New Year's Eve. South Australia Adelaide Cup Day gets a Monday public holiday on March 9 in SA. Tasmania Tasmania's public holidays vary throughout the state. Parts of Tasmania will get a day off on February 9 for the Royal Hobart Regatta. Some areas will observe a day off for the Royal Hobart Show on Thursday, October 22, while others will have a public holiday on Monday, November 2, for Recreation Day. Victoria The Friday before the AFL Grand Final is a public holiday in Victoria, with the game held on the last Saturday in September. This year, the public holiday will fall on September 25. There will also be a public holiday for Melbourne Cup Day on Tuesday, November 3. Western Australia WA observes an additional Anzac Day holiday on Monday, April 27, and Western Australia Day on Monday, June 1.

A full list of holidays for each state can be found on the Fair Work website.

How can you make the most of annual leave?

If you have annual leave banked up, you may be able to use this in conjunction with public holidays to maximise consecutive days off.

Four days of annual leave in April — 7, 8, 9, 10 — becomes a 10-day break with the Good Friday and Easter public holidays.

Careful planning can turn seven days of annual leave into a 16-day break over the summer holidays. ( )

Taking annual leave on Friday, June 5, leads to a four-day weekend with the King's Birthday on the Monday, except in Queensland and WA.

And getting organised in advance for the 2026/27 Christmas season can see seven days of annual leave turned into a 16-day holiday break.

Just take annual leave days off on December 21, 22, 23, 24, 29, 30, and 31.

For the average full-time worker in Australia with four weeks of annual leave, that will leave you with eight days of annual leave left over.

title: Islands rich in history, marine life and debate about their names
text:
They might be among the best-kept secrets in the Illawarra, but the five islands off Port Kembla on the New South Wales South Coast are rich in both history and marine life.

They can even inspire some spirited debate about what they should be called.

For thousands of years, the islands held significant importance for the Wadi Wadi people, who shared stories about their creation through the Dreaming.

George Bass, Matthew Flinders and William Martin battling the storm in the "Tom Thumb" off Providential Cove. (Supplied: From the collections of WCL and Illawarra Historical Society. P06573)

But in the early 1800s, famed explorers George Bass and Matthew Flinders, aboard the Tom Thumb II, charted and named the islands after themselves and their servant boy William Martin.

Excerpt from the Illawarra Aboriginal History Poster, Early Contact Map. (Supplied: Coomaditchie United Aboriginal Corporation)

Cobbyr became Flinders Islet, also known as Toothbrush Island.

Munnungang became Bass Islet and Booirodoong, the largest, was renamed Big Island, also called Rabbit or Perkins Island.

The smaller islets on either side of Booirodoong are called Martin Islet and Rocky Islet.

The story of five islands

Aunties Narelle Thomas and Lorraine Brown are visual artists and elders at Coomaditchie United Aboriginal Corporation. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Sisters Narelle Thomas and Lorraine Brown are among those determined to keep the story of the islands alive.

Both accomplished artists, they created a 21-metre mural to tell the Dreaming creation story of the islands at Hill 60 in Port Kembla.

The Story of Five Islands, a Dreaming Story book produced by Coomaditchie United Aboriginal Corporation, also tells the tale, including illustrations of the six sisters, Geera, Mimosa, Wilga, Lilli Pilli, Wattle and Clematis, produced by local children.

"Our tribal people would have probably told this story many times … we do want people to know that there is Dreaming stories in the Wollongong area and we're very proud of this," Ms Brown said.

Dreaming stories, known as Alcheringa by the Aboriginal people of the Illawarra, explain the creation of land, culture, and laws. (Supplied: Coomaditchie United Aboriginal Corporation)

"Mount Keira is a woman's area and six sisters lived up there, the six daughters of Oola-boola-woo, the west wind."

Ms Brown said the creation story detailed what happened to cheeky children who did not do their chores.

"There was one that was very naughty and very cheeky, and he really had enough of her, so he picked her up on a piece of the mountain and threw her out to sea," Ms Brown said.

A 21-metre mural depicts the Dreaming story of Oola-boola-woo and his six daughters at Hill 60 in Port Kembla. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

According to the story, Oola-boola-woo eventually threw five daughters out to sea, who became the five islands of Port Kembla.

"It's a beautiful Dreaming story, even though he blew them out to sea," Ms Brown said.

"Eventually, the daughters turned into mermaids that swim around the islands.

"The daughter left up there was Geera, and she sat on the mountain until she was covered by leaves and moss, becoming the top of the mountain, which is now Mount Kiera."

Birds, seals and penguins

Nathalie Simmonds takes tours around Five Islands Nature Reserve. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

The islands also boast a rich array of marine life.

Nathalie Simmonds, Abyss Project director and University of Wollongong PhD candidate, is studying marine biology in intertidal protected areas. She also conducts tours of the Five Islands Nature Reserve.

"Of all the islands, there is only one which is actually an island, which is Big Island, so the rest are islets, which means that it's not large enough to support human life," she said.

"Extensive studies have been undertaken about the wildlife that lives on each island, and where they hold both national and international significance."

Named after navigator Matthew Flinders, this islet's Aboriginal name is Cobbyr. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Cobbyr, or Flinders Islet, is dominated by an intertidal zone.

"It's rocky around the edges and supports the vulnerable sooty oystercatcher as its preferred habitat," Ms Simmonds said.

The furthest from shore is Munnungang or Bass Islet, also a rugged intertidal zone.

Tourists are drawn to the spectacle of south coast seals, which sleep in packs by the water's edge. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Martin Islet is home to a bachelor seal colony.

"We are starting to see a change in the population on Martin Islet, with females in the last year starting to colonise during the July winter months," Ms Simmonds said.

A pelican colony on Big Island, also known as Booirodoong. (ABC Illawarra: Justin Huntsdale)

Booirodoong, or Big Island, is the largest of the islands where the majority of bird species live, including a colony of pelicans.

"Come September, the island is completely covered with migratory sea birds such as white-bellied sea eagles and our shearwaters. It's also an important habitat for the little penguin," Ms Simmonds said.

"Rocky Islet is the smallest of the five islands, and will occasionally have a seal or two, and of course, migratory sea birds," she said.

title: Are you ageing well? Try these 4 simple tests to find out
text:
Advertisement

LifestyleHealth & wellnessAgeing Are you ageing well? Try these 4 simple tests to find out Dana G. Smith January 26, 2026 — 1:31pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Take a minute to consider the last decade of your life. What type of physical shape do you hope to be in? And what are the activities you want to be able to continue doing?
